17. Terminology; division of the material. We will use the term “lived world” (Umwelt) to name any of the everyday worlds of meaning that we inhabit. We will study such lived worlds as a way of getting at the structure of meaning as such. The German prefix “um-” (“around”) in the term Umwelt does not mean the physical space around us but refers to ex-sistential spatiality, which we referred to above in § 12 (SZ 53g, 56b) and will clarify below in terms of meaning.
• Section A will analyze how we deal with the practical things we first encounter in our lived worlds of meaning.
• Section B will show that Descartes’ notion of the world as res extensa vs. res cogitans was an attempt to explain spatiality, but overlooked ex-sistence.
• Section C will explain the peculiar spatiality of ex-sistence and of our lived worlds of meaning.
How this chapter will unfold. Chapter Three progresses as follows:
Section A, § § 15-18: The lived world of meaning and its essential structure
Section B, § § 19-21: Our position contrasted with that of Descartes
Section C, § § 22-24: The spatiality of ex-sistence and of the lived world of meaning
